BOFFA: I think we are all partly right. Yeller is a phenomenon that exceeds our categories. She is not simply supernatural, as Grigsu claims, but she is not simply natural, as Yasho claims. She is something in between, something that our language has not yet found words for.

YASHO: Our language has not found words because there is nothing to find words for. Yeller is five women. The mystery is manufactured.

GRIGSU: The mystery is real. You refuse to see it because seeing it would require you to abandon your precious dissolution.

[The argument continued for another hour, growing more heated. Twenty-one stones were cast by the stone-school adherents present, an unusually high number. The debate was ruled incomplete, with no winner declared.]

ETHICS OF DOCUMENTATION
The Gilt Cardhouse, Capital
Evening of the Fourteenth Day of the First Month, 883

Present: Yasho Krent, Mink Pavar, various observers
Topic: The ethics of expedition documentation

YASHO: I have been reviewing Mink's histories of the Quarry expeditions. I find certain discrepancies between his accounts and the original expedition reports.

MINK: Discrepancies are inevitable. I synthesize multiple sources. I interpret. I contextualize.

YASHO: You also omit. You selectively quote. You present conclusions as though they were facts when they are merely your opinions.

MINK: Every historian does this. History is not a mirror of the past. History is an interpretation of the past.

YASHO: There is a difference between interpretation and distortion. Your account of the Fifth Expedition makes it seem as though the disaster was caused by the crew's incompetence. But the original reports suggest environmental factors that no one could have predicted.

MINK: The original reports were written by survivors. Survivors have an interest in blaming anyone but themselves.

YASHO: And historians have an interest in constructing narratives that serve their purposes. What purpose does your narrative serve, Mink?

MINK: I serve the truth. I try to understand what actually happened and why.

YASHO: Do you? Or do you serve the water-school, constructing histories that support our philosophical positions?

MINK: I am not aware of doing so. If you have specific examples, I would be happy to address them.

YASHO: Very well. Your account of Grigsu's expedition in 869 says that he returned 'shaken by his encounter with the inexplicable.' But Grigsu's own report says he returned with increased conviction in the permanence of words. You have characterized his experience in a way that supports dissolution, when his own account supports persistence.

MINK: Grigsu's report was written months after his return. By then he had reconstructed his experience according to his philosophical commitments. My account tries to capture what he actually felt at the time, before his theories took over.

YASHO: How do you know what he felt at the time? Were you there?

MINK: I spoke with members of his crew. I gathered testimony.

YASHO: And you believed the crew over the expedition leader?

MINK: I weighed the evidence.

YASHO: Mink, I am on your side philosophically. I believe in dissolution. I believe the stone-school is wrong. But I am troubled by your methods. History should not be a weapon in philosophical warfare.

MINK: History is always a weapon. Every history serves some purpose. The question is whether the purpose is good and the means are honest.

YASHO: Are your means honest?

MINK: I believe so. I do not deliberately falsify. I do not invent events that did not happen. I select and interpret, as all historians must.

YASHO: Selection is power. Interpretation is choice. You have the power to shape how future generations understand the past. That power should be used with humility.

MINK: I am humble. I acknowledge my limitations. But I also believe that some interpretations are better than others, that some truths are worth emphasizing, that history should serve the cause of understanding.

YASHO: Whose understanding? Understanding of what?

MINK: Understanding of how language works. Understanding of why the water-school is correct. Understanding of why clinging to stones is a mistake.

YASHO: Then you admit it. You write history to serve the water-school.

MINK: I write history to serve the truth. The water-school is the truth. The two cannot be separated.

[The debate continued, but Yasho's concerns were not resolved. Several observers noted that Mink seemed defensive, even evasive. Yasho produced evidence that damaged Mink's reputation, though no formal charges were brought. Seven stones were cast.]

THE KACHOT DISPUTE
The Gilt Cardhouse, Capital
Evening of the Ninth Day of the Third Month, 886

Present: Grigsu Haldo, Mink Pavar, various cardhouse regulars
Game: Kachot
Stakes: Twenty marks and scholarly reputation

The dispute began in the seventh round. Grigsu had accumulated a commanding lead using what he called 'the old rules' of kachot. Mink challenged a scoring sequence involving the third knot.

MINK: You cannot count the knot twice. The hook releases once.

GRIGSU: Under the old rules, the knot counts at binding and at release. Two scorings.

MINK: There are no 'old rules.' There are rules. The knot counts once.

GRIGSU: This is how we played in the villages. This is how Yasho and Boffa and I played twenty years ago in this very cardhouse.

MINK: I have been playing kachot in this cardhouse for fifteen years. I have never seen anyone count a knot twice.

GRIGSU: Because you play with swindlers who have corrupted the game. The new rules favor the cheat.

MINK: Are you calling me a swindler?

GRIGSU: I am calling your rules illegitimate. I am calling the manner of play in this house a degradation of the true game.

MINK: And I am calling your so-called old rules an invention to cover your losses when they come. Which they will.

[At this point the cardhouse master intervened, examining the knot in question and ruling that house rules, which specify single counting, would apply. Grigsu protested.]

GRIGSU: Then I withdraw from the game. I will not play by corrupted rules.

MINK: You withdraw because you see your lead evaporating. Your precious stones are dissolving, Grigsu.

[Grigsu stood abruptly, knocking several hooks to the floor, and departed without casting stones or settling his account. The cardhouse master noted the breach of protocol. Mink was awarded the forfeit and the pot.]

MINK: [to the assembly] This is who the stone-school produces. A man who cannot lose gracefully. A man who invents rules to suit his position. Remember this when you read his treatises.

[Later that evening, after Grigsu's departure]

OBSERVER: Was that necessary, Mink? The man was clearly upset.

MINK: Grigsu is always upset when reality does not conform to his expectations. He thinks words are stones, permanent and unchanging. He thinks game rules are stones too. But rules change. Meanings change. Grigsu cannot accept this.

OBSERVER: Still. He is a respected scholar. You embarrassed him in front of the whole cardhouse.

MINK: He embarrassed himself. I merely pointed out what everyone could see.

OBSERVER: Yasho will not be pleased. She disagrees with Grigsu but she respects him.

MINK: Yasho is too soft. The stone-school must be defeated, not accommodated. Grigsu and his casting of stones and his village superstitions, these things should be laughed out of the Capital. The water-school will never triumph as long as we treat stone-carriers with kid gloves.

OBSERVER: You seem to have a personal grievance.

MINK: I have a philosophical grievance. Grigsu's ideas are dangerous. They encourage people to cling to the past, to resist change, to hoard meaning as though it were gold. This is bad for language, bad for thought, bad for the city.

OBSERVER: Well. The pot is yours, at any rate.

MINK: Yes. And his reputation is damaged. Two victories in one night.

EVIDENCE OF FORGERY DEBATE
The Gilt Cardhouse, Capital
Evening of the Twenty-Ninth Day of the Eleventh Month, 911

Present: Mara Yent, Mink Pavar, Donal Crest, various observers
Topic: Evidence of forgery in stone-school manuscripts

MARA: I have spent two years examining the manuscripts attributed to Grigsu Haldo after his death. I have found troubling anomalies.

MINK: What kind of anomalies?

MARA: Vocabulary anomalies. The posthumous texts use words that Grigsu never used in his verified writings. Specifically, they use water-school terminology: dissolution, residue, flow. Grigsu was a stone-school partisan. He would not have used these words.

MINK: Perhaps Grigsu was changing his views at the end of his life. Perhaps he was moving toward the water-school.

MARA: There is no evidence of such movement in his verified late writings. His last authenticated treatise, written just months before his death, is entirely consistent with his earlier positions.

MARA: I have also found historical anachronisms. One of the posthumous texts refers to the Third Surveying Expedition in a way that suggests the author knew its outcomes. But that text is supposedly dated before the expedition returned.

MINK: Dating errors are common in manuscript attribution. The text may have been misdated.

MARA: Or the text may have been written later than claimed, by someone who knew the expedition's outcomes.

MINK: What are you suggesting?

MARA: I am suggesting that these posthumous texts may not be genuine. I am suggesting that someone may have created them after Grigsu's death and attributed them to him.

MINK: That is a serious accusation. Who would do such a thing?

MARA: Someone who wanted to discredit the stone-school. Someone who wanted to make it appear that even Grigsu, the stone-school's greatest champion, had abandoned his positions at the end.

DONAL: Mara, are you accusing someone in this room?

MARA: I am not making accusations. I am presenting evidence. The evidence points where it points.

MINK: I discovered these manuscripts. You are suggesting that I forged them.

MARA: I am suggesting that the manuscripts are not genuine. I am not attributing motive or authorship.

MINK: But the implication is clear. I discovered them. I have been the chief promoter of them. If they are forgeries, I am the obvious suspect.

MARA: I have made no accusations.

MINK: You have made implications, which are just as damaging. I demand that you either accuse me directly or withdraw your insinuations.

MARA: Very well. I will continue my investigation. When I have conclusive evidence, I will present it.

MINK: There is no evidence because there was no forgery. The manuscripts are genuine. Grigsu changed his mind at the end of his life. This is not uncommon. Many people reconsider their positions when death approaches.

MARA: Perhaps. But the evidence does not support that interpretation. The evidence supports the interpretation that these texts were created by someone other than Grigsu, sometime after his death.

[The debate continued without resolution. Nineteen stones were cast. Mara Yent's investigation continued until her death eight years later, at which point her notes were found to be incomplete and water-damaged.]

GRIGSU'S LOST TREATISE
[Discovered 902, attributed to Grigsu Haldo, composed allegedly 868]

I have reconsidered everything.

The dissolution of which Yasho speaks is not the enemy of meaning. It is the medium of meaning. I was wrong to resist it. I was wrong to cast my stones against the flowing water.

Consider what happens when we speak. The breath shapes itself, yes. But the shape is already dissolving as it travels. By the time it arrives at the listener, it has begun to merge with all the other shapes, all the other words, all the other meanings that have ever been spoken.

This is not loss. This is how understanding happens. The residue of my word mixes with the residue of every word my listener has ever heard. From that mixture, meaning precipitates.

I was a fool to think words were stones. Stones do not mix. Stones do not combine. Stones sit in their places and weather to dust. But wordswords live precisely because they dissolve.

The expedition to Yeller Quarry opened my eyes.

I saw Yeller on the road, the five-fold being, and I thought at first I was seeing proof of my theories. Five distinct figures, persisting, not dissolving into each other.

But I was wrong. I saw what I wanted to see. What I actually witnessed was dissolution in action. Five women becoming one being through the very process Yasho describes. Their individuality dissolved into something greater. Their words and thoughts and movements merged into a single flow.

Yeller is not proof of the stone-school. Yeller is proof of the water-school. Yeller is five drops becoming one pool.

I must tell Yasho she was right. I must recant my errors before I die. The stones I have cast must be gathered up and thrown into the river.

I think now about my grandmother and her teaching about casting stones. I thought she was honoring words by casting stones after them. I thought the stones were tributes to permanence.

But perhaps I misunderstood. Perhaps the stones were offerings to dissolution. Perhaps by casting them aside, we acknowledged that words, like stones, eventually dissolve into the earth. Perhaps the ritual was not about preservation but about release.

The water-school speaks of the pool that receives all words. My village had no pool, but we had the earth. Every stone we cast dissolved eventually into the soil. Every word we spoke dissolved eventually into the collective memory of the village. The two dissolutions were parallel, the stone into earth, the word into community.

I have been fighting against what my grandmother was trying to teach me. I have been clinging to stones when I should have been letting them go.

My final years have been lonely. I have driven away my friends with my stubbornness. Yasho no longer debates me because there is no sport in defeating someone so clearly wrong. Bagbu still visits, but he pities me more than he respects me. Mink has publicly mocked me in the cardhouses.

I deserve this isolation. I have been wrong, and worse than wrong, I have been rigid. I have refused to see what was obvious to everyone else. I have clung to my position like a man clinging to a rock in a river, thinking the rock made me strong when actually it just kept me from flowing.

The water-school is correct. Words dissolve. Meaning is collective. Nothing persists unchanged. I should have admitted this years ago, when the evidence was already overwhelming. Instead I wasted decades defending an indefensible position.

Let this treatise serve as my recantation. Let it dissolve into the pool of collective meaning along with everything else I have written. Let future generations know that even Grigsu Haldo, the stubborn stone-carrier, eventually learned to swim.

THE TRUE STONE-SCHOOL
[Discovered 904, attributed to Grigsu Haldo, composed allegedly 869]

What I have called the stone-school is a corruption of the true teaching.

The true teaching is this: words are like stones that fall into water. They exist for a moment as distinct objects. Then they sink. Then they dissolve.

The falling is real. The distinctness is real. But so is the dissolving.

I have fought against Yasho for too long. I have pretended that words remain forever hard, forever separate, forever retrievable. But this is not the true stone-school. This is the false stone-school of my village, the superstitious stone-school of backward people who cast pebbles after conversation.

The true stone-school acknowledges that the stone falls into the pool. The seventy pools of Mirado receive all words eventually. The question is not whether words dissolvethey dobut what patterns they leave as they sink.

I have been to Mirado. I have seen the pools. I have watched the water cycle through the pipes, up from the reservoir and back down again. Nothing persists there. Everything flows.

And I understood, watching those pools, that Eulr was right. The residue of every word ever spoken in Mirado floats in that water. When you drink from the pools, you drink dissolved meaning. When you speak into the pools, you add your meaning to the collective.

This is not frightening. This is beautiful. The pools of Mirado are the physical embodiment of linguistic communion. Every citizen connected to every other citizen through the medium of the water, through the residue of shared speech.

My village practice of casting stones was an impoverished version of this. We cast stones into the dirt, not into pools. Our words had nowhere to go, no collective to join. That is why we clung to the fantasy of permanence. We had no pool to dissolve into.

I want to apologize to Yasho. I have been harsh with her in our debates. I have called her ideas foolish when they were actually wise. I have dismissed her arguments when I should have listened.

Yasho understood from the beginning what I am only now learning: that dissolution is not death but transformation, that the pool is not a grave but a womb, that words are not stones but water, temporarily hard, eventually flowing.

I hope it is not too late to make amends. I hope Yasho will accept this treatise as evidence of my change of heart. I hope we can debate as friends now, seeking truth together instead of fighting over positions.

The true stone-school and the water-school are not enemies. They are aspects of the same truth. Words fall and words dissolve. Both things happen. Both things matter. I have spent my life emphasizing the falling and ignoring the dissolving. Yasho has spent her life doing the reverse. Perhaps together we can see the whole.

RECANTATION OF ERRORS
[Discovered 906, attributed to Grigsu Haldo, composed allegedly 870]

I have been in error.

For twenty years I have taught that words are permanent, that meaning persists, that the stone-school offers truth where the water-school offers only mysticism.

I was wrong. I recant.

The water-school is correct. Words dissolve. Meaning dissolves. Even the self that speaks dissolves. We are all temporary patterns in a universal flow, like eddies in the seventy pools.

I have seen the evidence with my own eyes. On my expedition to Yeller Quarry, on subsequent journeys I have not publicly documented, I have witnessed the dissolution that Yasho describes. I have felt my own words dissolving as I spoke them. I have felt my own self beginning to dissolve.

This is not frightening. This is liberating. The stone-carriers burden themselves with weight they need not carry. Let the words go. Let the meanings go. Let the self go.

Join the flow.

I want to explain why I clung to the stone-school for so long.

I was afraid. I was afraid that if words dissolved, nothing would matter. I was afraid that if meaning was collective, I would have no individual significance. I was afraid that the pool would swallow me and I would cease to exist.

These fears were childish. The pool does not swallow. The pool receives. The pool transforms. When I dissolve into the collective, I do not cease to exist. I become part of something larger, something that includes everyone who ever spoke and everyone who ever listened.

The stone-school was my defense against this terrifying expansion. By insisting that words were permanent, I could pretend that I was permanent too. By clinging to my stones, I could pretend that I mattered as an individual, separate from the flow.

But I do not want to pretend anymore. I want to accept the truth, even if the truth is frightening. The truth is that I will dissolve. The truth is that my words will dissolve. The truth is that nothing I do will persist unchanged. And this truth is not a tragedy. This truth is a relief.

To my students, if I have any left: forget what I taught you.

Forget the permanence of words. Forget the casting of stones. Forget the fantasy that meaning can be preserved like grain in a jar.

Learn instead from Yasho. Learn that words flow. Learn that meaning is made and remade in every moment of understanding. Learn that the pool is not a threat but a gift.

I wasted my life fighting against the current. Do not make my mistake. Join the flow. Let the dissolution take you. Trust that what emerges on the other side will be richer than what went in.

This is my last teaching. This is my recantation. This is my surrender to the truth I should have accepted long ago.

The water-school was always right. I was always wrong. Let this be remembered, and then let even this remembering dissolve into the pool where it belongs.

ON THE RECONCILIATION OF SCHOOLS
[Discovered 907, attributed to Grigsu Haldo, composed allegedly 871]

I have been thinking about reconciliation.

The stone-school and the water-school have been at war for generations. We have debated in cardhouses and lecture halls, hurled arguments like weapons, treated each other as enemies rather than seekers of the same truth.

But what if both schools are partially correct? What if the truth lies not in either position but in their synthesis?

The stone-school says words persist. The water-school says words dissolve. Perhaps both things happen. Perhaps words persist for a time and then dissolve. Perhaps permanence and impermanence are not contradictory but sequential.

A stone dropped in water persists as it falls. Then it reaches the bottom and begins to erode. Eventually it dissolves entirely. But for a time, it was both hard and wet, both distinct and surrounded, both persisting and dissolving.

I propose a new philosophy: the school of falling stones.

In this school, words are neither permanent nor immediately dissolved. Words are in process. Words are falling through the medium of understanding, passing through minds, changing as they go, eventually dissolving into the collective but persisting for a time along the way.

This synthesis preserves what is correct in both schools. The stone-school is right that words have some persistence, some hardness, some resistance to immediate dissolution. The water-school is right that dissolution is the ultimate fate of all words, that the pool receives everything eventually.

The disagreement was never about the endpoint. Both schools agree that words eventually become part of something larger. The disagreement was about the duration. The stone-school insisted on eternal persistence. The water-school insisted on immediate dissolution. Both were wrong. The truth is in between: temporary persistence, eventual dissolution.

I imagine Yasho reading this and laughing. She will say I am trying to save face, trying to claim partial credit for views I once entirely rejected. She will say this reconciliation is just the stone-school in retreat, conceding everything while pretending to concede nothing.

Perhaps she is right. Perhaps I am rationalizing. Perhaps the honest thing would be to simply admit defeat and join the water-school without reservations.

But I cannot help feeling that something is lost in pure dissolution. If words dissolve immediately, if there is no persistence at all, then communication seems impossible. How can you understand me if my words have dissolved before they reach you?

The water-school has answers to this question, I know. They speak of parallel dissolution, of similar patterns forming in similar minds. But these answers feel like evasions to me. They describe coordination without explaining it.

The school of falling stones offers a better explanation. Words persist long enough to be received. Then they begin to dissolve. Communication succeeds because there is a window, a moment of hardness, during which meaning can be transferred. After that window, dissolution takes over. But the window is real. The persistence is real, even if temporary.

MAPS AND MEMORY: A WANDERER'S NOTES
Being the ongoing memoir of Vagabu Olt, called Bagbu

People call me Vagabu, Vag. Gab, Buva, Bagbu. My motherif I had onecalled me Vagabu. It is the name I remember in songs sung to me by some woman I vaguely feel at my back. With Grigsu and his lotthe scholars properit was always Bagbu. I think maybe it was a rhyme with Grigsu, thinking types, word men, being what they are.

It would be lying a little to call myself a scholar. I am no such thing, was never. Grigsu and Yasho, they were thinkers, paid for their work and set up with the finery of a mastered craft: disciples and hangers-on, money at hand and an easy demand for their speeches anywhere they went. Not me. My pickbox cart bulged with papers and ideas, maps and diagrams, but little in all that paper had the numbers and figures of currency writ on it.

I rumbled into a town and set up whatever shop I could, stayed for a time, and then packed up and rumbled down the road to the next.

The road itself whispers nothing but what's nearest along it. Roadsigns are charlatans. Maps, mere soothsayers. The road is its own four feet at a time.

Those first days of travel, after Grigsu died and I decided to find his village, gave me time to wonder. And as all wondering leads toward puzzles, I found myself wrapped up in one conundrum after another.

Some were the little toys of children: can a small stone be bigger than itself? Is a hole the nothing in it or the something around it? If we discover that Jorkin did not build the tower of Mirado, is Jorkin the person who did not build the tower? Or does Jorkin become the person who did build the tower, whoever that may be? And if the former, do we all become Jorkin, save the one of us who did build the tower?

I became, pleasurably, two question marks on either side of a parenthesis.

Then one night in my least favorite cardhouse in the Capital, drinking and playing kachot with all those swindlers who play with these new rules, I admit I was feeling quarrelsome.

I threw out as a kind of challenge or bet: 'What do any of you know about anything? Which of you cheating bastards has ever done anything? I used to play this game the old way with real scholars. Grigsu. Yashoshe was a great, she was a towering intellectnone of you could lick her toes. I once played with Grigsu in this very house. And now what? What's left of him now? What are we doing here?'

I admit I grew emotional and was not making sense. And I was overplaying Grigsu's talent as a kachot scholar. And certainly Yasho. Such idiots, both of them, in their own ways.

But a person grows older. A person starts to wonder what makes anything worthwhile.

I should say something about my cart.

The pickbox cart was given to me by a man I will not name, in payment for a map I drew of a region he wanted to reach but could not find. The cart has been my home for thirty years now. It has compartments for everything: papers, food, clothing, tools. It has a bed that folds out from the side. It has a small stove for cold nights. It is larger on the inside than it appears from the outside, though I do not know how this is possible.

I have been told the cart is haunted. I have been told the cart was built by witches. I have been told the cart contains a portal to another world. I do not believe any of these things, but I do not disbelieve them either. The cart is strange. The cart keeps its secrets.

When I am on the road, the cart makes noises. Creaks and groans, like any wooden vehicle. But sometimes the noises sound like words. Sometimes I could swear the cart is trying to tell me something. I have never been able to make out what.

I reached Grigsu's village after many weeks of travel. It was smaller than I expected, poorer, more isolated. The houses were made of rough stone and mud. The streets were unpaved. There was a smell of woodsmoke and animal dung.

But the people were welcoming. They remembered Grigsu. They were sorry to hear he had died.

An old woman named Threnn told me stories about Grigsu as a boy. How he was always arguing, always asking questions, always insisting that words meant exactly what he said they meant. She laughed when she told me this. 'He never changed,' she said. 'He went to the Capital and became a famous scholar, but he was still the same boy who argued with his grandmother about whether the sky was blue or the color of blueness.'

I asked about the stone-casting. She showed me the piles of stones outside every house. 'We cast them to remember,' she said. 'Every conversation that matters, we cast stones for. The stones remember even when we forget.'

I asked her if the stones really remembered. She looked at me like I was simple. 'Of course they don't. They're stones. But we remember better when we cast them. That's the point.'

I stayed in Grigsu's village for a week. I drew maps of the area. I recorded stories. I cast stones after every conversation, as they did.

On my last night, Threnn came to see me. She brought a small leather pouch.

'These were Grigsu's,' she said. 'From when he was a boy. He forgot them when he left for the Capital. I've been keeping them for him. Now I suppose they're yours.'

Inside the pouch were seven smooth stones. Each one was different: different colors, different shapes, different textures. They had clearly been selected with care, polished with handling.

I asked what they were for.

'For counting,' she said. 'Before he learned to argue about words, Grigsu was interested in numbers. He carried these stones everywhere, counting everything. The number of birds in a tree. The number of steps from his house to the well. The number of words in a sentence.'

I took the stones. I carry them still. Sometimes, when I am trying to understand something difficult, I take them out and count them. Seven stones. A prime number. Grigsu would have appreciated that.

THE TESTIMONY OF SONTER
Recorded on the night before his execution
By the Daughter of the Chief of Police

The man in the cell would not give his true name. 'You can call me Sonter,' he said. He was the only survivor of the expedition into the deep Quarry, the one led by the woman they called the Boss. He had walked out of the Dens carrying a leather bag. Inside the bag were heads.

I had seen them when my father brought the bag from the outskirts bar to the jail. The heads of three men with identical dark hair. The heads of three women: one with black stubble for hair, one with a long white braid, one with a close red braid like the battlements of a castle. The heads of the five-fold Yeller and of their mistress, the Boss.

Sonter could not speak at his trial. The catcalls drowned him out. But on this last night, with only me to hear him through the bars, he told me everything.

'The Boss was a witch,' Sonter said. 'Not the Yeller kind. A different kind. She told us there were no witches in the Dens, no monsters, nothing to fear but our own superstitions. She said we were on an expedition of science.

'But Gull knew. He'd been warning us from the start, telling stories by the fire about road crews sucked dry by witches, about the densmuck that dissolves everything it touches. The Boss said Gull had a lively imagination. Said we shouldn't let his bedtime stories keep us from the most lucrative night's work we'd ever have.

'So we followed her into the cave. Twenty-three of us went in. The Boss, the five Yeller, seventeen men. We lit torches and walked into the dark.'

Sonter stopped here. I asked what happened in the cave.

'Yeller happened,' he said. 'Not the Boss. Not any monster. Yeller.'

'Black Yeller pulled a blade from somewhere in her clothes. I didn't see where. One moment she was walking behind the Boss, same as always. Next moment the blade was out and she was walking through the other Yeller, through the three men and the two women, to reach the Boss.

'The Boss started to turn. She was fast, the Boss. But not fast enough. Her head hit the ground before her body knew what happened.

'Then Black Yeller turned to the Yeller men. One by one. Then to White Yeller. The blade drew back and forth like breathing. When it was done, only Black Yeller was standing, and she walked to Gull and put the blade in his hand and pointed to her own throat.'

I asked Sonter why. Why would Yeller destroy itself?

'I don't know,' he said. 'But when Gull did what she wanted, when he cut and the head fell, I swear I saw Black Yeller smile. Like she'd been waiting for that moment her whole life. Like she was finally going home.'

I asked Sonter what happened after the killing.

'We bagged the heads,' he said. 'Gull's idea. He said there was a law, an old law, that the heads had to be brought out. I don't know what law he meant. Nobody argued with him. We put the Boss at the bottom and piled Yeller in on top of her.

'Then we tried to leave. But we couldn't find the way. The cave went on and on, passages that doubled back, rooms that opened into other rooms. We walked for days. Men died. Some from thirst, some from accidents, some from just giving up.

'I was the last one. I don't know how I made it out. I just kept walking, carrying the bag, until I saw light. And then I kept walking until I found a town. And then I walked into a bar and put the bag down and waited for someone to help me.'

I asked if he killed them. If he was the one who swung the blade.

'No,' he said. 'But I would have. If Black Yeller had handed the blade to me instead of Gull, I would have done it. We all would have. There was something in that cave, something in the way she looked at us. We would have done anything she asked.'

That was the last thing Sonter said to me. In the morning, they hanged him.

SONGS OF STONE
A Collection
By Tam Whistle

I. THE WORD BEFORE THE WORD

Before the first word was spoken
there was the silence waiting for it,
hard as stone, patient as stone,
the tablet on which that word would be carved.

And when the first word was spoken
some say it was 'yes' and some say 'no'
and some say it was a name for fire
the silence did not dissolve.

The silence held the word the way
a mountain holds a cave,
the way a riverbed holds water
that has long since flowed away.

Speak your word. It will not drown.
The silence is stone enough to hold it.


II. FIVE

Five women on the road at night.
Five voices calling out their curse.
Five bodies moving as one body.
Five words that are one verse.

Who speaks them? No one and all.
Who hears them? The darkness does.
What do they mean? They mean themselves.
What were they? What Yeller was.

III. CASTING

My grandmother cast stones
after every word that mattered.
She said it was to remember.
She said the stones would know.

I cast stones too now,
though I am far from her village,
though no one here understands,
though the stones fall on city streets
where no one stops to wonder.

The stones do not remember.
The stones are only stones.
But I remember better
when I hold them in my hand,
when I feel their weight and hardness,
when I let them go.


IV. GRIGSU

He argued and he argued,
word against word, stone against stone.
He would not bend, he would not flow,
he stood where he was planted.

They mocked him in the cardhouses.
They laughed at his casting.
But he was right about one thing:
words are harder than we think.

I watched him die slowly,
not of disease but of rigidity.
He hardened until he cracked.
But the words he spoke survive him.

Rest now, Grigsu. Rest in stone.
Your words will not dissolve.

V. THE PRIME SONG

One is the number of loneliness,
the self that speaks to silence.
Two is the number of meeting,
the word that finds an ear.
Three is the first true oddness,
the triangle of meaning.

Five is the number of Yeller,
the hand that grasps the world.
Seven is the number of mystery,
the days it takes to travel.
Eleven is the number of patience,
the years between the questions.

Count on your fingers. Run out of fingers.
Start again. The primes keep coming,
indivisible, persistent,
stones in the riverbed of numbers,
words that will not wash away.


VI. BAGBU'S CART

There is a cart on the north road
that creaks in a language of its own.
The man who drives it draws maps
of places that do not exist
until he draws them.

I have ridden in that cart.
I have heard its wooden speech.
It said: nothing is permanent
except the road itself,
and even the road changes
when the cartographer arrives.

Draw your map, Bagbu.
Draw the world into being.
The rest of us will follow
the lines you leave behind.

DISSOLUTION SONGS
A Collection
By Lira Canto

I. THE DROP

I spoke a word this morning.
It fell from my mouth like water,
like a single drop into the pool
where all drops go.

I cannot find it now.
I search the surface
for the ripple of its landing.
Nothing. The pool is still.

But the pool is larger now
by one drop's worth,
and somewhere in that larger pool
my word swims with all the others,

dissolved into the everything,
meaning nothing on its own,
meaning everything together,
meaning what water means: flow.


II. THE SEVENTY

The seventy pools of Mirado
hold every word ever spoken there.
Not preserved like stones in a vault
but dissolved like salt in the sea.

Drink from any pool,
you drink the words of founders.
Speak into any pool,
your words join the founders' words.

There is no retrieval.
There is no archaeology of meaning.
There is only the drinking
and the speaking and the flow.

III. AGAINST THE STONES

Grigsu casts stones, they say,
in his study in the Capital.
He fills jars with pebbles
to remember what was said.

Poor Grigsu. The stones remember nothing.
The stones are only weight.
He carries the past in little jars
while the past flows on without him.

Let go the stones, Grigsu.
Empty your jars into the river.
Watch the pebbles sink and roll
and disappear downstream.

Your grandmother was wrong.
The words do not need honoring.
The words are already gone
into the pool that needs no jars.


IV. EULR AT THE POOL

I watched Eulr at the muddy fountain
at the bottom of Mirado.
He was old then, near the end,
speaking to the specks of dirt.

'You are what remains,' he said.
'You are the residue of everything.
The words dissolve around you
and you persist, tiny monuments.'

I asked him what he meant.
He said: 'Even dissolution has its limits.
Even the pool has a bottom.
Even meaning leaves a trace.'

Then he died, and I watched
his last breath dissolve into the air,
and I wondered if the specks of dirt
would remember him.

V. THE FORGETTING

There is a kindness in forgetting.
The word that hurt you once
dissolves into the pool
and cannot hurt you again.

The promise that was broken
dissolves into the pool.
The lie that was believed
dissolves into the pool.

The pool does not judge.
The pool receives all equally.
The word of love and the word of hate
become the same water.

Drink and forget.
Speak and release.
The pool is always ready
to take what you cannot carry.


VI. YASHO DYING

They say Yasho is dying now,
the great dissolver, the water-teacher.
She is dissolving into her own doctrine,
becoming what she always taught.

I will miss her voice, her arguments,
the way she could silence Grigsu
with a single raised eyebrow.
I will miss her certainty.

But she would not want me to hold on.
She would not want me to cast stones.
She would say: let me go,
let me join the pool I always praised.

So I let her go.
I watch her dissolve.
And the pool grows richer
by one great teacher's worth.

DANNKIT'S LINGUISTIC NOTES
From the papers of Dannkit Rosh, stonebreaker

I am nearly deaf from all the hammering. This is what the trade does to a man. But deafness teaches you something about words that hearing never could.

When you can barely hear, you watch mouths. You watch hands. You watch the whole body speak. And you learn that the sound coming out of the mouth is the smallest part of the word.

Grigsu would have understood this, I think. He and I never spoke much when he was wellhe was a Capital man and I was villagebut after he came back from the Quarry all changed and growling, I was the one who could sit with him. Because I did not need to hear his words. I could see them.

The body speaks before the mouth. The hands speak. The shoulders. The feet. I watched Grigsu's feet in those last days and they told me everything. They were trying to walk somewhere they could not find.

Grigsu finally told me what happened in the Quarry. Or he tried to tell me. His mouth made the shapes and some sound came out and I caught maybe one word in three.

But his body told me the whole story.

Something had shaken him down to his stones. Something had made him doubt everything he had built his life on. His theories about words, his arguments with Yasho, his certaintyall of it crumbled in those Quarry caves.

I asked him what he saw. His mouth said something I could not catch. But his hands said: five. His body said: they were one thing that was five things that was one thing.

Yeller. He had seen Yeller. And Yeller had broken something in him that could not be mended.

I kept bringing him food and sitting with him. That was all I could do. Words would not have helped him even if I could have heard them.

In my years of stonebreaking, I have learned something about words that the scholars do not know.

Words are not stones. Words are not water. Words are something stranger than either.

When I break a stone, I feel the stone's resistance. The stone does not want to break. The stone pushes back against my hammer. And when it finally breaks, there is a moment of release, like a sigh, like a breath let go.

Words are the same. Words resist being spoken. Have you noticed this? It is hard to say exactly what you mean. The words push back. They want to remain in the silence, in the potential, in the not-yet-said.

And when you finally speak, when the words finally come out, there is that same release. That same sigh. You have broken something open. You have let something go.

Grigsu died in the spring. I was with him. He had not spoken clearly for days, just mumbles and growls. But at the end, he suddenly sat up, looked at me, and said one word.

I could not hear it. My ears are too far gone. But I watched his mouth make the shape, and I knew what word it was.

He said: stone.

Then he fell back and was gone.

I cast seven stones for him, one for each decade of his life. I cast them in a line pointing toward the Quarry, toward whatever he had seen there, toward whatever had broken him and made him.

The stones lie there still, I imagine. Nobody has moved them. Nobody will. They are just stones, after all. They mean nothing without someone to remember.
